WPP Briefing Paper 46359 Water Policy Programme
No. 5, November 2004
Towards Better Integration of Water and Sanitation in PRSPs in Sub-Saharan Africa1
Lessons from Uganda, Malawi and Zambia
Poor Integration of Water and Sanitation in PRSPs
With the increased prominence of Poverty Reduction A major premise in the PRSP approach is that the StrategyPapers(PRSPs)insettingnationalpolicyagendas participatory process of developing a PRSP will help and mobilizing resources within developing countries, it build political commitment. Donors and civil society is becoming increasingly important for sectors to engage can, through supporting such participatory processes, in the PRSP process. However, the Water and Sanitation help provide the external impetus needed to ensure Sector (WSS) has been poorly integrated into PRSP and that poverty reduction remains on the political agenda. budgetary processes, contrasting sharply with sectors However, there is no guarantee that this will create suchasEducationandHealththatarelentgreaterpriority commitment. It is still inconclusive whether participatory in PRSP documentation, and subsequently benefit from processes can build the levels of political commitment larger resource allocations. required for PRSPs to become instruments that can be implemented and actually deliver results. This brief examines why WSS has not fared well in PRSP processes in Africa. Based on a study commissioned by the Water and Sanitation Program­Africa, the paper analyzes the integration of WSS in PRSPs in three Sub- Saharan African countries ­ Uganda, Zambia and Malawi ­ and compares this to generic experiences in Education andHealthsectors.Itprovidesrecommendationsonhow WSS actors can better align themselves towards PRSP process and take actions to help the sector gain priority in PRSP and budget processes.

The `WatSan & PRSPs' project was coordinated by the Overseas Development Institute (ODI), in partnership with WaterAid, and in collaboration with the Water and Sanitation Program-Africa, as well as with researchers and policy specialists in the region ­ and was supported by the UK Department for International Development-DFID.  Three common features can be identified from sectors support, because, ex ante, they tend to have larger in Uganda that are closely aligned with PRSPs. As illustrated in Figure 1 below, Uganda is far ahead of Zambia and Malawi in terms of development of sector reforms (SWAps) and the PRSP process itself. This, combined with a strong and sector-focused budgetary process, has strengthened coordination within and between sectors. doc.repnme: Towards better integration of water and sanitation in PRSPs in Sub-Saharan Africa : lessons from Uganda, Malawi and Zambia
doc.abstracts: This brief examines why water and sanitation sector (WSS) has not fared well in poverty reduction strategy paper (PRSP) processes in Africa. Based on a study commissioned by the water and sanitation program-Africa, the paper analyzes the integration of WSS in PRSPs in three Sub- Saharan African countries - Uganda, Zambia and Malawi - and compares this to generic experiences in education and health sectors. It provides recommendations on how WSS actors can better align themselves towards PRSP process and take actions to help the sector gain priority in PRSP and budget processes.
